group.name: Multichannel Hello World!
group.sample: This page shows how a simple XML page can be presented in HTML.

This is the same page above, but rendered in XHTML (which is the well-formed XML version of HTML). Note that both the page and the stylesheet used to transform it didn't change from the previous example, Cocoon does everything for you by setting a different serializer.

By changing the stylesheet, it's possible to render the same content for consumption on different devices. Here, for example, is rendered in WML (Wireless Markup Language) which is the markup language used in WAP-enabled agents (such as PDA or cell phones).

Given the power of XSLT and the fact that many presentation languages are based on the XML syntax, it is possible to generate even vector graphics from your content. Here is an example that renders to SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics). (you need an SVG plugin, or an SVG-capable browser to see this)
Sometimes you don't need to be very fancy, so here is a plain text version of your content.
But sometimes you need to ve fancy to impress people, so here is a 3D version of your content (you need a VRML plugin in your browser to visualize this)
Or sometimes you don't even have a display in front of you, so you want to hear your content, so here is a VoiceML representation of your content (you need a VoiceML-capable agent to hear this).
